captions.text: Hello ladies
Looks like it's just you and me today for TL:DR
because Martina still doesn't have her voice back
So i'm gonna do all the speaking by myself
and unless she uses her hand puppet
which won't really  contribute too much in this discussion
and your general out of edification about things in Korea
So today, the question fortunately directed just at me
As shazwales asked what are some issues of being tall in Korea
since I'm so tall what are some things that I deal with
So for you who doesn't know
I'm roughly 6"4 or 195cm in Korea
which whenever I tell people that I'm 195cm like
whoah!
Baek gu sib oh!
Baek gu sib oh!
Yes, I am Baek gu sib oh!
in heights
Actually it comes with a bit funny side story
Around two years ago,
there was small controversy
which one girl on TV show
said that she wouldn't date anybody under 180cm
because she said those are
"LOSERS"
so, when i started telling people that I'm 195cm
they were like
"WINNER~"
Even when we went to Everland which was like an amusement park in Korea
they had the height restrictions
and we even saw 180cm
someone actually penciled in 'loser' below that so
that was kinda funny
Actually, I was too tall to fit on one of the rides
according to the height restrictions
so i actually had to hunch over in order to get on the ride
so that's one of the problems living in Korea
if you are my height
you might not get onto the amusement park rides
Not very safe for people like me
So, now are there a lot of tall guys in Korea?
Well, not that many that I have seen around in my height
Sure, some tall guys exists
I've actually ran into couple that are taller than me
but I quickly depose of their body so nobody will never find them again
Excellent
There can be only one
But another than that
nobody is really my height at all
I pretty much tower everyone that I see clearly
everybody's head here in Korea
So the main issue that living in Korea because of my size is
clearly clothing
I can't find anything here to fit me
shirts, sometimes i can find pants
Shoes, absolutely impossible
because I have size 13feet
which is roughly size 300
So essentially no shirts,
no shoes,
no service
for me
Now you can go to places like Itaewon
and get bigger size of clothing
but that is only for specific style of clothing
which isn't necessary my aesthetic
So mainly if I wanted to go to department stores
or funky Korean stores,
i'm not gonna be able to find any Korean cloth that fit me
Maximum size that goes up to is roughly 110
which I don't know what that means
110 is the biggest
and according to those standards I'm roughly like
which they don't make
Well, other issues that I face in Korea
apart from not finding clothes
is practically not fitting in this country
I don't mean in terms of me being weird
I just don't physically fit in lot of places in this country
Korea is a very high population density
and the real estate is very limited
so lot of restaurants can be a little bit cramped
i find myself trying to like
squeeze through doorways
and squeeze around people
trying to fit somewhere
tables sometimes are too small for me
especially floor tables
If I ever have to sit on the ground and cross my legs
I can't get my legs underneath the table whatsoever
Pretty much i have to sit on the side
all like sexy model style
like, Hello~ ladies
This is the only way that I could sit on the floor tables in Korea
One another thing about Korean restaurants is that
lot of them have like dangling light fixtures
which result in me bumping my head against them all of the time
making unpleasant restaurant experience
I had some odd experience on wash rooms as well
because the washrooms are also very cramped
and since my legs are too long
when i'm trying to sit down
and do number 2
my legs won't actually fit against anything
so i have to prompt them up to the wall
my feet dangling
which makes a very awkward sensation when you are trying to crawl one out
Hey, I'm trying to tell the story here
Some toilets you might not be able to poop in
alright? you should remember that tall guys
or tall girls
Pooping might be difficult for you
in public spaces
And there are some great benefits of being tall and big as I am
This odd thing that happens in korea sometimes
which when you are on the subway and it's your stop
and you're trying to get off
some people trying to squeeze on before they actually let you off
And me, personally, I find that annoying
So whenever anybody tries to do that I just puff up like this
and I walk straight and they all just bounce right off me
they actually have to like back paddle because they trying to squeeze pass me
Just learn how to way people
Just learn how to way
and really busy crowded areas
also very easy for me to find Martina
because I could look over to everybody's head
and just see the little blonde girl with pink hair
It's easy
Now, you want a high five?
okay
There's your high five
You're hands are warm
sick
Why is it so warm?
gross. Martina's hand have a heating disorder
It's good for Martina as well  when we are in crowded areas
because everybody is bumping off her
she would just walk behind me
and use me as a snow plow
like everybody bounces off me
I'm making it sound just as like I walk though Korea
like push everybody around
but that's not necessary the case
this just means that people try bump into me
will face negative repercussions
I'm like the Dothraki man Warriors
cleaving through crowds of Korean people
Not necessarily true
I don't have cleaver
Also subway has lots of dangling advertisements
which I sometimes have to like
limbo around
so i don't bump my head against to it
sexy limbo
this is how I go through the limbo sizer
just like that
look at that cleavage
So that's it for todays TL:DR
I know it's shorter
It's only because it's the half the team here today
and one obnoxious hand
If there is a question that you want us to answer for next week TL:DR
Leave your questions in the comments
And if we like your questions
we might just pick it
And if we don't like it
we might not pick it
And hopefully by next week Martina's voice will be back
or else we'll have another just sexy one on one session with you and me
that's right ladies
and awkward hand over there
And don't' forget to like and favorite this video
and subscribe for more TL:DR Wednesdays
Take it away awkward hand
really hands suppose to do a dance
or suppose to do the bloopers right here
bloopers here, pass week there
uh yah

comments.text:

about him being 6' 8''... He already bangs his head on door frames and low

comments.author: Simmer Princess

comments.text:
My son is also 6' 4" tall and due to his taller than average height have 
had many comical experiences of his own the last time we were in Korea. 
Anyway, for a boy who grew up in the house with a 10 foot ceiling it was 
quite a challenge having to adjust to ceilings barely tall enough clear the 
top of his head. Especially  whenever he was going in and out of the rooms 
and kept forgetting to duck his head in time. As a result resounding 
smacking forehead right into door lintel noise was what how we could guess 
whether the boy was in the vicinity or not. Same thing on the buses until a 
mere reminder of"duck!" itself was enough to get him so irritated. Oh well, 
you know about having to folding and squeezing long limbs to fit little 
space between seats all too well so I won't even bother to mention. 
However, it still was overall wonderful experience that my son can't wait 
to go back. How about that...!﻿

averege male height. Any other tall girls out there? ﻿

problem is not my height. The problem is my weight. I'm like 92 pounds 
(about 42 kg) so I have a weird looking body. It's like I can't even gain

to be shorter. Also, the guy I like is like 5'6 but he's like 13 so :/

comments.author: Lydia Gray

comments.text:
I think you saying that you tower over everybody is highly exaggerated. The 
average male height in Korea is 174cm and in the US the average white male 
has a height of 177cm (and it's the same in the UK). A difference of 3cm 
isn't that great, since the standard deviation for male heights is 7cm. So 
3/7 of a standard deviation isn't that much though nontrivial﻿
comments.author: G. EEXHU54

comments.text:
I don't think you've ever stood next to someone who was 20 centimeters 
taller than you with the way you're talking. There's no way you would think 
that someone standing an entire head over you is not "towering" over you.
comments.author: Jongseong Lee

comments.text: He just said that he is 190+ cm if you were listening
comments.author: funnybunny puppy

comments.text:
He's 195 cm, meaning there is a 21cm difference in height between him and 
the average Korean male. 21cm is roughly 8 inches, which means he can 
easily see over people of average height.
comments.author: Brandon Kim

comments.text:

comments.author: UittoniiSuni

comments.text:
Oh! And I do want you to know that I do know that there are variables that 
I cannot account for etc. and that stats need to be taken with a grain of 
salt at times but they are useful for proving a point and are a solid idea 
of what the general avg. is.
comments.author: UittoniiSuni

comments.text:
Haha. I'll keep the Northern China avg. height in mind when I go to Beijing 
this Feb. ;D
comments.author: UittoniiSuni

comments.text:
Yes, I agree that at smaller distances between individuals, height 
differences are most apparent to each observer. 

Those statistics may be outdated. Also, they may have differing 
methodologies and sample sizes. But aside from those points, I don't think 
that these samples should be treated so seriously up to the hundredths 
digit, so to speak: depending on the sample, it could have well been the 
case that the average male height in HK was smaller than the average male 
height in Taiwan by 0.25cm. For instance if you look up different studies 
of Taiwan male height (and HK too) you'll probably figures that are 
certainly different up to the hundredths digits. 

I think that saying the average male height in both HK and Taiwan surpasses 
171cm is a pretty safe statement; however after the units digit, things may 
not be as reliable. Based on (somewhat old) statistics, average male height 
in Taiwan and HK is probably about the same. (Makes sense as the vast 
majority of Taiwanese are from Fujian, which is quite "genetically 
homogeneous" to Guangdong and hence HK.)

Regarding your observations, you *might* also have seen an 
uncharacteristically taller set of people in HK and / or an 
uncharacteristically short set of people in Taiwan. (Though I'd rule the 
latter out given that you live in Taiwan, so it's probably merely the 
former, which is quite possible due to the fact that your duration of stay 
was a week.) 

Of course it's also perfectly possible that people from HK truly are taller 
than people from Taiwan. 

But to address your intended point: Hmm, I don't really think 0.25cm would 
be sufficient to account for such a large perceived height difference. It's 
too small.   So it's one of two things: either you observed an 
uncharacteristically tall set people in HK and/or HK people are taller by 
more than 0.25cm. 

Sorry for the long write-up. If you ever go to northern China you might be 
even more taken aback. Northern Chinese males are the tallest in China (and 
Asia), at 175+ cm. :-)
comments.author: G. EEXHU54

comments.text:
+G. EEXHU54
I agree with you overall but the main reason (I believe) "short" people and 
"tall" people have various ideas about what is tall is because of how the 
neck is positioned when looking at something. For shorter people they have 
to look up constantly to meet a tall persons eyes whereas a tall person 
does the opposite. Unless the height difference is small the angle in which 
you are looking at a person can emphasize a person's height. Especially to 
your own.

A good example of this is when you want to take a picture of a tall 
building but can't get far enough away without obstructing the view. You go 
down to the ground and tilt the camera up to get the entire building but in 
doing this you also make the building look much taller than if you were 
looking at it straight on.﻿

Though I agree that homogeneity and inhomogeneity both play a role I can 
safely say that even a little bit of height difference does indeed make a 
difference. I live in Taiwan right now and the avg. height for a male is 
171.45 cm (5' 7.5") and the avg. height for a woman is 159.68 cm (5' 2.75") 
and just this past month I went to Hong Kong for a week and the avg. height 
for a man is 171.7 cm (5 ft 7 1⁄2 in) and for women is 158.7 cm (5 ft 
2 1⁄2 in). While I was only there for a week and Hong Kongers (sp?) are on 
avg. about .35 cm (1/2") taller than the avg. Taiwanese I could still tell 
that they were taller and I felt much smaller even though I had not known 
the statistic at the time (I looked it up later because I couldn't 
understand why I felt they were taller when I was there. Thought it might 
have been because I was in a new country and had never been there before. 
XP).

Hope this makes sense and that my spelling was OK. ><
comments.author: UittoniiSuni

comments.text:
A displacement of three sevenths of a standard deviation is actually 
sufficient to account for the rough 1-in-10 versus 1-in-5 difference that 
you've observed due to the fact that the bell curve diminishes more and 
more rapidly as it descends toward its tails. Remember that it's not 
linear. I've looked into studies of this trait (height) and other traits in 
the past and it's not convincing that the standard deviation varies across 
different populations that share similar socioeconomic states; the 
population distribution usually falls within a bell curve-like histogram 
with very few exceptions, when a sufficiently large sample is taken. In 
fact, if anything in more developed countries with similar socioeconomic 
statuses the standard deviation is smaller due to the relative elimination 
of malnutrition and other factors which would stretch out outliers on the 
tails of the curve; there is more of a "normalized" 
nutritional/environmental standard for the population. 

I find it a little strange that you think studies on average height in the 
US would somehow leave out outliers in their data collections; this is 
almost certainly a false statement. However I understand what you are 
trying to say: the US indeed has a less homogeneous population due to 
relatively greater genetic diversity. Due to relative inhomogeneity in the 
US—as opposed to Korea—different sub-populations will have different height 
distributions and that's probably where the observation comes from.
comments.author: G. EEXHU54

comments.text:
I'm assuming you've lived in the USA which is why I find it a little weird 
on why you think its exaggerated. I think the average US male height 
doesn't account for how many extremes there are. Living in the states, it's 
not uncommon to find a lot of people who are 185-195. Bring me 5 random 
males and I'm sure one is going to fall under that range. But then again, I 
also see a lot of short males that are in the 160-170 range. I think Korea 
is a lot more normalized and has a narrower bell curve in terms of height. 
I see about 1 in 10 people who are in the 185-195 range currently in Korea 
(i'm visiting family), and I think its because Korean height is much more 
normalized to a bell curve compared to US male height. Considering how it 
feels to stand next to a person who is 5 inches taller than you, I think 3 
standard deviations above the average height is pretty "towering." I mean, 
that's like the length of a head.

+NormanZavlandid1066 The northern parts of the Netherlands are way taller, 
almost 10 cm or so, I think. The reason is that in our history, the north 
was inhabited by Frysian people who were tall, with scandinavian influences.

The south, however, was invaded by spain. Which is why there are shorter 
people, and why you will find more people with dark or black hair in the 
south, and blond hair in the north.
